title: Condition of Farm Labour in Eastern Germany
text:
Condition of Farm Labour in Eastern Germany (in German: Die Verhältnisse der Landarbeiter im ostelbischen Deutschland) is a <a href="book">book</a> written by <a href="Maximilian%20Weber">Maximilian Weber</a>, a German <a href="economist">economist</a> and <a href="sociologist">sociologist</a>, in 1892. Note that the original edition was in German and the title can be translated as "Condition of Farm Labour in Eastern Germany".
In 1890 an <a href="Voluntary%20association">association</a> (known as <a href="Verein%20f%C3%BCr%20Socialpolitik">Verein für Socialpolitik</a>) of scholars, government officials and other specialists decided to study the situation of <a href="landowner">landowner</a>s in Germany. Weber assumed responsibility for reviewing data from German provinces east of the <a href="Elbe">Elbe</a> River.
The situation in that part of Germany was influenced by the influx of <a href="migratory%20worker">migratory worker</a>s from <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, with special regards to <a href="Poland">Poles</a> and Russians, while the German labourers wanted to increase their upward <a href="social%20mobility">social mobility</a>, especially by changing the traditional <a href="labour%20relation">labour relation</a>s of that region (workers could only become labourers on annual <a href="contract">contract</a>).
However, their demands and expectations were actually putting them in a weaker position regarding the economic struggle for survival, as they were less <a href="competitive">competitive</a> than migratory workers.
Weber analyzed those changing labour relations as a symptom of widespread changes in the entire German society.
